title: Symbolism, Cognition, and Political Orders
Linguistic Relativity Revisited
RECKONING WITH RACE IN THE NEW WORLD (University of Virginia Press)
summary:
Under contract, University of Virginia Press, Writing the Early Americas Series. 

 Reckoning with Race in the New World represents the merging of my two principal research fields when I wear my early (Latin) Americanist hat: the history of science and the history of the race concept.  My first book, Sceptres and Sciences in the Spains (Liverpool, 2000), was the first transatlantic account of the history and philosophy of modern experimental science and conquest in the early modern Spanish world (Spain, Italy, Mexico, Peru).  

With the publication of my second book, Hierarchy, Commerce, and Fraud in Bourbon Spanish America (Vanderbilt, 2005), I began to propose that pre-Darwinian notions of human diversity were rooted in an animal-vegetable-human continuum distinct from the epistemology and animal-human divide of modern race science.  This second antecedent of RECKONING WITH RACE IN THE NEW WORLD focused on local negotiations and socio-legal notions of human kinds or groupings (castas) in colonial Latin America, and it has had a visible impact on anthropologists and historians.

title: johnjmcgraw.com
Bengali Kinship: An Inquiry into the Native Categories
summary: The study was carried out among the Bengali informants in Kolkata city by using methods of participant observation along with some of the techniques of cognitive anthropology and ethnoscience.Componential analysis was also employed to analyse kinship terms.The application of the technique of spontaneous listing to identify the kin-universe as done by David Schneider and C.B.Cotrell was done.The study revealed unlike the findings of Ralph Nicholas and Ronald Inden that Bengalis distinguish between kin and non-kin and they use a variety of lexico- cultural categories to designate the domestic group which is subsumed under the western category named 'family'. There is a large arena of fictive kin group among the Bengalis but that that does not mean Bengalis' inability to distinguisn between kin and non-kin.

title: Counterintuitive Progress: A Retrospective and Prospective Examination of MCI Theory
Formes de la transmission familiale des patrimoines olfactifs : partager l'être affecté
Extending the counter-intuitiveness effect: Implicit theories of social behaviour and the cognitive impact of the counter-cultural
summary:
Much attention in the study of cognition and culture has focused on innate ‘folk theories’ about the world, which implicitly guide human behaviour. Cultural concepts that minimally violate the assumptions contained within these theories have been shown to possess a cognitive advantage in terms of their likelihood to be remembered and spread. This paper explores the possibility of parallel phenomena operating at the cultural level. Drawing on
research in social and cross-cultural psychology, it makes the case for a ‘folk social psychology’: a set of implicit assumptions about human social behaviour that is acquired through socialisation and cultural transmission, and thus varies with cultural context. Ideas or narratives which contradict these assumptions might have a similar psychological effect as
those countering the assumptions of innate folk theories, though they will differ in important respects. The paper concludes with an illustration of this phenomenon in the case of adherents to a radical socialist ideology, and argues that the approach might enhance our understanding of the attraction of counter-cultural ideologies.

title: Effect of outcome and controllability on the content of counterfactual thinking
summary: Counterfactual thinking (CFT) refers to the process of reflecting on an event and changing (mentally) aspects of it so as to alter the eventual outcome. Structurally, it could be additive (addition of aspects that were not in fact present) or subtractive (subtraction of aspects that were present) or substitutive (involving both an explicit deletion and an explicit addition of aspect). Previous studies have not focused on the relation between controllability and content of CFT. Current study (N=42) investigates the role of two variables “outcome” (better vs. worse) and “controllability” (controllable vs. uncontrollable) respectively on the content (additive, subtractive, and substitutive) of CFT with the latter being the within-subjects variable. Each participant was given two scenarios. Participants were asked to list any number of things in any order that, had they been different, would have improved the performance. Then participants completed controllability ratings for the four antecedent events for each scenario. The ratings confirmed that participants perceived more controllability for controllable than uncontrollable antecedent events. Total number and percentage of additive, subtractive, substitutive counterfactuals generated were computed and analyzed in all the experimental conditions. Overall, people generated more additive than subtractive or substitutive counterfactuals. There was no difference in the number or frequency of additive and subtractive counterfactuals as a function of outcome or controllability. However, the frequency of substitutive counterfactuals was more for worse than better outcome. Unlike past research, we do not find more CFT in general for worse outcomes and controllable antecedent events. Also, the present research indicates that in the presence of an explicit outcome and desirable direction for CFT, controllability may not matter for phrasing the counterfactual thoughts. Predominance of additive CFT supports the self-regulatory strategy of promotion focus.
